question_groups.description: Think about your organization when you answer the following questions and rate how strongly you agree or disagree with the following statements. In my organization...
questions: Information is actively sought
Responsibilities are shared
Messengers are not punished when they deliver news of failures or other bad news
New ideas are welcomed
Failures are treated primarily as opportunities to improve the system
Cross-functional collaboration is encouraged and rewarded

question_groups.description: Think about how your team and work are structured. For the primary application or service you work on, please rate how strongly you agree or disagree with the following statements.
questions: On my team, we can make large-scale changes to the design of our system without creating significant work for other teams
To complete my own work, I don’t need to communicate and coordinate with people outside my team
My team can deploy and release our product or service on demand, independently of other services it depends upon
We can do most of our testing on demand, without requiring an integrated test environment
On my team, we can make large-scale changes to the design of our system without depending on other teams to make changes in their systems
On my team, we perform deployments during normal business hours with negligible downtime

question_groups.description: Sustainability of work is important, and burnout is an important indicator of this. Please answer a few questions about how your work has affected you. Please rate how strongly you agree or disagree with the following statements:
questions: My feelings about work negatively affect my life outside of work.
I feel like I am ineffective in my work.
I am indifferent or cynical about my work.
I feel exhausted.
I feel burned out from my work.

question_groups.description: The next set of questions are about the change approval process. For the primary application or service you work on, please rate how strongly you agree or disagree with each of the following statements.
questions: I have a clear understanding of the process to get changes approved for implementation
I am confident I can get changes through the approval process in a timely manner
All significant changes must be approved by a senior manager prior to implementation
We have a formal process to approve changes to applications or production systems prior to implementation or release
Production changes must be approved by an external body (e.g., change approval board, manager, etc.) before implementation or deployment
For all the types of changes that I typically make, I know the steps it takes to go from “submitted” to “accepted” every time

question_groups.description: Please rate how strongly you agree or disagree with the following statements in relation to your use of cloud services.
questions: The cloud my product or service runs on serves multiple teams and applications, with compute and infrastructure resources dynamically assigned and re-assigned based on demand
I can monitor or control the quantity and/or cost of cloud resources used by the service or product that I primarily support

Once I have access, I can independently provision and configure the cloud resources and capabilities required for my product or service on demand without raising tickets or requiring human interaction
I can dynamically increase or decrease the cloud resources available for the service or product that I primarily support based on demand

The service or product that I primarily work on is designed to be accessed from a broad range of devices (e.g. smartphones, tablets, laptops) over the network without the need for proprietary plug-ins or protocols

question_groups.description: For the primary application or service you work on, please rate how strongly you agree or disagree with each of the following statements.
questions: When people get feedback that the system is not deployable (such as failing builds or tests), they make fixing these issues their highest priority
We can deploy our system to production, or to end users, at any time, on demand
Fast feedback on the quality and deployability of the system is available to anyone on the team
Our software is in a deployable state throughout its lifecycle
My team prioritizes keeping the software deployable over working on new features

question_groups.description: The next set of questions ask about committing code and building and deploying software at work. For the primary application or service you work on, please rate how strongly you agree or disagree with the following statements.
questions: Code commits result in a series of automated tests being run
Automated builds and tests are executed successfully every day
Code commits result in an automated build of the software
Automated test failures will block a commit’s progress through the pipeline

question_groups.description: The following questions ask about documentation. We define documentation as internal documentation for the services or applications you work on (e.g., manuals, readmes, code comments, etc.). End-users are not the audience for these documents. Please rate how strongly you agree or disagree with the following statements.
questions: Technical documentation is updated as changes are made
It is easy for me to understand our technical documentation
I can rely on our technical documentation when I need to use or work with the services or applications I work on
Our technical documentation is well organized
When there’s an incident or problem that needs troubleshooting, I reach for the documentation
It is easy to find the right technical document when I need to understand something about the services or applications I work on
The technical documentation correctly reflects the capabilities and requirements of the primary service or application I work on
Most of the code for the services or applications I work with is documented

question_groups.description: In an average week, approximately what percent of your time at work is spent...
questions: completing operations related tasks (e.g., troubleshooting production problems, collecting metrics and logs, monitoring dashboards, monitoring logs, responding to incidents), if any?
actively coding (e.g., writing new code, improving existing code, fixing bugs, testing, designing and architecting code), if any?
completing administrative tasks (e.g., planning, meetings, emails), if any?

question_groups.description: Think about the degree to which your organization uses new technology. To what extent do you agree with the following?
questions: My organization uses outdated processes and technologies
My team does not have the freedom to explore new technologies

question_groups.description: For each of the following performance indicators, how well did your organization meet its goals over the past year?
questions: Your organization’s overall profitability
Your organization’s overall performance
Relative market share for primary products
Increased number of customers

question_groups.description: Making predictions isn’t easy, but some people find it helps them better express their perspective. Please indicate how unlikely or likely you think the following events are for the primary service or application you work on.
questions: We will start using a new product in the next 90 days
We will have an outage due to quota or capacity misunderstanding in the next 90 days
Someone is let go from the team  in the next 90 days
We will invest more to reduce risk for dependencies in the next year
We will have a significant performance degradation in the next year
Leadership will sponsor one or more software security initiatives in the next year
We will invest more to improve our deployment security and monitoring in the next year
We will invest more to improve our build systems in the next year
We will have an increased spending budget for new tools in the next year
We will increase the amount funding for getting new tools in the next year
We will see an increase in multi- and/or hybrid-cloud adoption in the next year
We will see a decrease in on-premises solutions/data centers in the next year
We will be compromised by a security vulnerability in the next year
We will have a complete service/product outage in the next year
Someone quits in the next 30 days
We will have an emergency code or configuration change in the next 30 days

question_groups.description: These next questions ask about reliability, and how you and your team think about it. For the primary application or service you work on, please rate how strongly you agree or disagree with each of the following statements.
questions: It has well-defined targets for reliability (such as Service Level Agreements / Service Level Objectives) that are clearly communicated among the team and to customers
Reliability reviews are performed throughout the development process for all major features on the applications I work on
I know what its reliability actually was in the most recent period
When we miss our reliability targets, we perform improvement work and/or re-prioritize
My team regularly reviews and revises reliability targets based on evidence
My team actively identifies and eliminates, automates, or streamlines repetitive manual work (sometimes called "toil")

question_groups.description: Now let's focus on your team's alerting strategy. For the primary application or service you work on, please rate how strongly you agree or disagree with each of the following statements.
questions: Alerts are generated based on service degradation from the perspective of end users or dependent systems (as opposed to system metrics like CPU %, ICMP latency, or disk IO)
Alerts are configured so that humans are only paged when an immediate response is needed

question_groups.description: We'd also like to understand how your team prepares for incidents or changes in capacity needs. For the primary application or service you work on, please rate how strongly you agree or disagree with each of the following statements.
questions: My team has well-defined protocols and tools for responding to production incidents
My team regularly practices incident response procedures
How often do your services meet reliability expectations (i.e., SLOs)?

question_groups.description: Please indicate the extent to which you agree with the following statements.
questions: I have access to the necessary tooling to execute security tests
We have ongoing efforts to monitor information coming from public sources regarding possible vulnerabilities in the software we use and its third-party components
At my company, we have a standardized process for addressing software security across projects
The software security processes that exist at my company slow down the development process for the applications I work on
At my company, the software-security protocol is seamlessly built into our development process
Security requirements are reviewed at regular intervals (annually, or sooner if required)
Our org has processes in place to identify and document all security requirements for the software our organization develops or acquires (including third-party and open source)
Security roles are integrated into our software development team
My organization has an effective method for identifying security threats
My organization has an effective method for addressing security threats
Security tests are run early in the software development process, either by me or by another team
We continuously engage in automated or manual code analysis and testing for all supported releases, in order to identify or confirm the presence of previously undetected vulnerabilities
Security review is conducted for all major features on the applications I work on
At my company, security practices are considered a box to check, rather than a fundamental part of the development process

question_groups.description: How established are the following practices for the primary application or service you work on?
questions: Build metadata (e.g., dependencies, build process, build environment) about an artifact cannot be edited by build services users
Every change in a revision’s history must be individually reviewed and approved by two trusted persons prior to submission
When running builds, build steps are prevented from loading any build inputs dynamically (i.e., all required sources and dependencies are fetched upfront)
Build metadata (e.g., dependencies, build process, build environment) about an artifact includes all build parameters
The build metadata (e.g., dependencies, build process, build environment) about how an artifact was produced is signed by my build service
Build metadata (e.g., dependencies, build process, build environment) is either generated by the build service, or by a build-metadata generator that reads the build service
Build metadata (e.g., dependencies, build process, build environment) is available to the people who need it (e.g. via a central database), and is delivered in a format that they accept
Builds are isolated; they cannot interfere with concurrent or subsequent builds
Revisions and their change history are preserved indefinitely
Build metadata (e.g., dependencies, build process, build environment) about an artifact documents all dependencies
Production releases are built by using a centralized CI/CD system, never on a developer’s workstation
Build definitions and configurations are defined in text files stored in a version control system
Builds are fully defined through the build script and nothing else
